stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on establishing the art style and initial layout for 'Course 12', a new cowboy-themed level. The stream involved extensive experimentation with building colors, textures, and fog, a detailed breakdown of the level's concept and missions, and a real-time reaction to a new music track from the composer that influenced the level's atmosphere.

development_findings.summary: After struggling to find an art style, Kaze used an AI art generator to create a 'goofy cartoon wild west town' concept, which became the breakthrough visual direction for the level.
development_findings.quote: This is what I want, actually.

development_findings.summary: The cowboy level, Course 12, is conceptually designed as a 'Wild West Valley' with three main areas, a focus on capturing three outlaw mini-bosses for stars, and quirky details like a saloon that only serves milk.
development_findings.quote: The saloon will only serve milk. And it looks better. I think so, too. But it's a bit awkward. We have to figure out the right style for the buildings first.

development_findings.summary: Adding atmospheric fog to the level, while visually effective, forces all materials to become '2-cycle,' which has a significant negative impact on performance on the N64. Kaze is weighing the aesthetic benefit against the technical cost.
development_findings.quote: Unfortunately, this means everything is going to be a 2-cycle material. Which is really, really bad. We've already experienced this in Oily Boily Bay. It might just look so good that we have to take the loss.

development_findings.summary: Kaze designed the town layout as a U-shape or donut around a central mountain. This is a deliberate choice to aid with object culling and manage performance on the N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: What if this whole city was kind of around a mountain? That would work well for the N64. Because of how much culling it allows.

development_findings.summary: The level will feature floating train tracks in the sky, a design decision Kaze justified by referencing the similar aesthetic in Wario's Gold Mine from Mario Kart 64.
development_findings.quote: It doesn't go through a canyon anymore. This one. Oh, well, it does go through a canyon, actually. Actually, this is just like Varys goldmine's train tracks.

development_findings.summary: One of the level's three core missions involves investigating a train robbery, with the culprit being five Goombas disguised as one tall person in a trench coat, who must be toppled over to initiate a boss fight.
development_findings.quote: There is a really tall Goomba in a trench coat with five cowboy hats on. And he's a little sus because he's wobbling when he walks. So you have to topple him over. And then you find five little Goombas.

development_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned that Nintendo took down his tutorials, indicating past friction with the company regarding the distribution of game modification knowledge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for the cowboy level is to create a 'cowboyaboo' or 'westaboo' experience—an over-the-top, goofy, and fun exaggeration of Western stereotypes, rather than a dark or gritty interpretation.
context_findings.quote: You know how people that pretend to be Japanese, like weeaboos, how they completely overdo Japanese culture or what they perceive to be Japanese culture? I want it to be that, but for cowboys.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's development pace on the project has decreased since he began a full-time job, indicating a significant external time constraint.
context_findings.quote: Development has slowed down ever since the end of course 9, because I have a full-time job now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong principle of only including references and inspirations in his game that he personally understands and appreciates.
context_findings.quote: I would never reference something that I don't enjoy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed disinterest and dismissal of a current online controversy, stating it doesn't affect him and isn't worth the attention it's receiving.
context_findings.quote: Guys, I actually care so little about the whole Twitch nudity thing, and I don't think it's interesting at all. And I don't know why so many people are talking about it... Who gives a shit? Just ignore it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze told a story about confronting a neighbor over a beeping smoke detector by sitting on a chair and staring into their window until they fixed it, revealing a direct and unconventional approach to problem-solving.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time art style feedback in the chat, suggesting Kaze look at a level from 'Beyond the Coast'. While Kaze initially found the suggestion unhelpful, he interpreted it charitably as advice to increase color saturation.
biobak.quote: You're making me look like an asshole Biobak. Uh, but giving it the most charitable possible interpretation, I think what you're saying is to make them more saturated.

badub.summary: Badub, the composer, sent Kaze a new music track for the cowboy level live on stream. The track was immediately praised by Kaze and directly influenced the level's atmosphere, prompting the addition of fog.
badub.quote: Oh, he got a song. Oh, this is so good. Yo. Oh, that's so perfect. I love this.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's spouse and project animator, was mentioned arriving home during the stream, but there was no direct professional interaction shown.

key_stories.title: Finding the Art Style with AI
key_stories.summary: Stuck on creating a compelling art style for the cowboy level, Kaze turned to an AI art generator after other inspirations fell short. The resulting 'goofy cartoon' image provided a breakthrough, giving him a clear and exciting visual direction to build towards.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was struggling to define an art style for the cowboy level that wasn't drab and monocolored, finding his initial attempts 'ugly' and uninspiring.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviewed various inspirations, rejected some community suggestions, and experimented with colors. Feeling stuck, he prompted an AI art generator for a 'goofy wild west town,' which produced a concept he loved.
key_stories.outcome: The AI-generated image provided a clear visual target. Kaze then successfully began replicating its vibrant, colorful, 'goofy cartoon' feel in-game by adjusting textures and color palettes, resolving his creative block.
key_stories.key_quote: This is what I want, actually.

key_stories.title: Music Inspiring the Atmosphere
key_stories.summary: The composer, Badub, sent a new music track for the level while Kaze was working on visuals. The song's quality and tone immediately inspired Kaze to add atmospheric fog, demonstrating a dynamic collaboration where music directly influenced the level's visual design in real-time.
key_stories.challenge: While the visual style of the level was being developed, its overall atmosphere and mood were still undefined.
key_stories.process: During the stream, composer Badub sent Kaze a new, unprompted music track for the level. Kaze played it live, was immediately impressed, and felt the song's vibe called for a more atmospheric environment.
key_stories.outcome: The music directly inspired Kaze to add atmospheric fog to the level. This decision significantly altered the scene's mood and helped solidify the overall aesthetic, leading to further experimentation with fog color and density.
key_stories.key_quote: But this song definitely makes me think we need to add fog to this level.

open_questions.context: Kaze is on Course 12, but mentioned he doesn't know how many stages are left. He also stated the missions in this level are disconnected and he doesn't want to do another level with a story right now.
questions: What is the target number of courses for the final game?
Is there an overarching narrative connecting the levels, or is the project a collection of distinct experiences?
What does the remaining roadmap for development look like?

open_questions.context: Collaboration with Badub (music) and Biobak (art) happened informally through DMs and live chat during the stream.
questions: How does the team typically collaborate when you're not streaming?
What is the process for providing feedback and iterating on major assets like music, art, and animation?
How did the initial concept for a cowboy level originate within the team?

open_questions.context: Kaze described his design goal for the level as being a 'cowboyaboo' or 'westaboo'—an affectionate, over-the-top parody of western tropes.
questions: Can you expand on this 'cowboyaboo' philosophy? Where do you draw the line between homage and stereotype?
Does this philosophy of creating a 'goofy, funny' take on a theme apply to other levels in the game?
What drives this preference for goofy parody over more serious or traditional interpretations?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that having a full-time job has slowed down the development of the project.
questions: How do you balance the demands of a full-time job with a massive creative project like this?
Has your professional work influenced your approach to this project, or has this project influenced your professional work?
How do you manage to stay motivated and avoid burnout?

open_questions.context: Zeina is a known animator on the project and Kaze's spouse. She was mentioned during the stream but her work was not discussed.
questions: What is the dynamic of working so closely with your spouse on a major creative project?
How are creative decisions and feedback handled between the two of you?
Could you describe Zeina's specific contributions to the animation we'll see in the game?
